entry.title: Information Overload 2011-07-10
entry.content:
• "US anti-piracy body targets foreign website owners for extradition":http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2011/jul/03/us-anti-piracy-extradition-prosecution
    Is anyone still shocked by news like this?
  • "Exclusive first interview with key LulzSec hacker":http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn20649-exclusive-first-interview-with-key-lulzsec-hacker.html?full=true
    I'm not sure how legit this interview is, better make up your own mind.
  • "Hobo Lobo of Hamelin":http://hobolobo.net/
    Awesome story-telling in HTML, CSS and JS. Can't wait for the next part.
  • "Who defaults first: Greece or the US?":http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14025485
    With all the attention on Greece, it's easy to overlook that the US are in a dire situation too.
  • "Portugal drug law show results ten years on, experts say":http://news.yahoo.com/portugal-drug-law-show-results-ten-years-experts-180013798.html
    Unfortunately this is very unlikely to have any effect on the "War on Drugs", but it's good news nonetheless.
  • "DNA is now DIY: OpenPCR ships worldwide":http://openpcr.org/2011/07/dna-is-now-diy-openpcr-ships-worldwide/
    Another very impressive achievement of the maker/DIY community.
  • "IRA VS. Al Qaeda: I was wrong":Comparing the tactics of the IRA and Al Qaeda. Some interesting food for thought, but I'd encourage you to draw your own conclusions from the provided information (like always).
  • "Associated Press Opening North Korea Bureau":http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/06/29/ap-associated-press-north-korea-bureau_n_887147.html
    Let's see how this goes, but I'm cautiously optimistic about this.
  • "Arab spring: an interactive timeline of Middle East protests":http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/interactive/2011/mar/22/middle-east-protest-interactive-timeline
    Another nice interactive infographic by the Guardian.
  • "Rhesus monkeys have a form of self awareness not previously attributed to them":http://www.physorg.com/news/2011-07-rhesus-monkeys-awareness-previously-attributed.html
    There's still so little we know about animals...

entry.title: Information Overload 2010-10-17
entry.content:
• "The 'Irrational' Way Humans Interact With Dentists":http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=130356647
    Are our relationships with our dentists a form of the "Stockholm Syndrome":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stockholm_syndrome? Ask the behavioral psychologist.
  • "RCA student radically improves the UK plug":http://www.iconeye.com/index.php?id=3864:rca-student-radically-improves-the-uk-plug&option=com_content&view=article
    Awesome redesign of an everyday item.
  • "William Gibson says the future is right here, right now":http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-11502715
    When it comes to the future, who to trust if not William Gibson?
  • "What a scientist didn't tell the New York Times about his study on bee deaths":http://money.cnn.com/2010/10/08/news/honey_bees_ny_times.fortune/index.htm
    Follow-up to last week's NYT article on "Colony Collapse Disorder":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colony_collapse_disorder. How is "Bayer":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayer related to all of this?
  • "Die kritische Masse":http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/0,1518,722673,00.html
    Interesting article on online review portals, user motivation and manipulation (in German).
  • "Whistleblower reveals 'systematic' humiliation of detainees":http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2010/10/whistleblower-reveals-systematic-humiliation/
    When reading things like this, "what goes around comes around" is always my first sad thought.
  • "The Numbers Game":http://structureofnews.wordpress.com/2010/10/12/the-numbers-game/
    A plea to increase "numeracy":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numeracy amongst journalists. Amen to that!
  • "Sweden joins Europe-wide backlash against immigration":http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/sep/24/sweden-immigration-far-right-asylum
    Sweden joins the ranks of European countries where xeno- and Islamophobia win elections. Also contains a short summary of similar developments all over Europe.
  • "Irish ISP wins major legal victory against record labels":http://www.techeye.net/internet/irish-isp-wins-major-legal-victory-against-record-labels
    UPC wins a court case against the record industry and does not have to implement a three strikes system for its customers (for now).
  • "Council of Europe Agrees That Net neutrality is Key to Freedom of Expression":http://www.laquadrature.net/en/council-of-europe-agrees-that-net-neutrality-is-key-to-freedom-of-expression
    Some more good news on the freedom of expression front.

entry.title: Information Overload 2010-10-09
entry.content:
• "How Fake Money Saved Brazil":http://www.npr.org/blogs/money/2010/10/04/130329523/how-fake-money-saved-brazil
    How Brazilian economists overcame hyper-inflation.
  • "Humor on the web & how to stop it":http://blog.bumblebeelabs.com/social-software-sundays-1-humor-on-the-web-how-to-stop-it/
    I iz in your memes, explaining dem. Oh, damn.
  • "Why is the Gates foundation investing in GM giant Monsanto?":http://www.guardian.co.uk/global-development/poverty-matters/2010/sep/29/gates-foundation-gm-monsanto
    The gates foundation is investing in GM giants Monsanto and Cargill. Is this their vision for agrarian development in Africa?
  • "Scientists and Soldiers Solve a Bee Mystery":http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/07/science/07bees.html?_r=1
    In the US scientists and the military teamed up to solve the mystery of "collapsing" bee colonies.
  • "Taking Uncle Bob to school":http://bestinclass.dk/index.clj/2010/10/taking-uncle-bob-to-school.html
    Lau Jenson goes through some Clojure code by "Uncle Bob":http://www.objectmentor.com/omTeam/martin_r.html and makes it more idiomatic.
  • "Later - What does procrastination tell us about ourselves?":http://www.newyorker.com/arts/critics/books/2010/10/11/101011crbo_books_surowiecki?currentPage=all
    A New Yorker piece on "The Thief of Time":http://books.google.com/books?id=Huw5YrMQ4icC&dq=%E2%80%9CThe+Thief+of+Time%E2%80%9D+Andreou;+Mark+D.+White;+Essays;+George+Ainslie;+George+Akerlof&source=bl&ots=SSIyiC2lqp&sig=_9LM9nZImBmWCqcy9wR4FW4KB6g&hl=en&ei=jXWvTKjfLsKeOrua_NUF&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CBYQ6AEwAg, a collection of essays about procrastination. Don't read this tomorrow, read it now!
  • "Confessions of a used-book salesman.":http://www.slate.com/id/2268000/pagenum/all/
    Interesting insight into what the person describing his job perceives as a shameful profession.
  • "A shocking discovery":http://www.nature.com/news/2010/101004/full/467645a.html
    In the late 1940s, the US Public Health Service infected Guatemalan prisoners with Syphilis.
  • "U.N. Report finds Israel 'summarily executed' U.S. citizen on flotilla":http://www.salon.com/news/opinion/glenn_greenwald/2010/10/01/flotilla
    Is anyone even surprised anymore?
  • "Wiretapping the Internet":http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2010/09/wiretapping_the.html
    Another excellent writeup by Bruce Schneier.

entry.title: Information Overload 2010-10-02
entry.content:
On a weekend trip again, but managed to squeeze in quite a bit of reading during the week.

  • "Friends Without Benefits":http://www.newsweek.com/2010/09/24/the-sad-truth-about-the-facebook-movie.html
    Was there a paradigm shift in Silicon Valley from hard science to pointless web 2.0 startups?
  • "How Universities Work":http://jseliger.com/2010/09/26/how-universities-work-or-what-i-wish-i%E2%80%99d-known-freshman-year-a-guide-to-american-university-life-for-the-uninitiated/
    As the title implies this is about universities in the US, but a lot of it also holds true for academic institutions in Europe.
  • "First World War officially ends":http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/8029948/First-World-War-officially-ends.html
    92 years after the end of the war, Germany will pay the last chunk of reparations imposed by the Treaty of Versailles.
  • "The Shell Hater's Handbook":http://shellhaters.heroku.com/#1
    Despite the name, this presentation by GitHubber "Ryan Tomyako":http://tomayko.com/ is a nice intro to shell scripting. If you know a shell hater, send him a link to this presentation.
  • "Virtual vs. Real Protests":http://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2010/09/29/can-twitter-lead-people-to-the-streets/virtual-vs-real-protests
    Twitter "revolutions" and the confusion between "mobilization" and "organization".
  • "Small Change":http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/10/04/101004fa_fact_gladwell
    Very much in the same vain as the previous article, Malcolm Gladwell talks about hierarchies vs. networks, strong vs. weak ties and why joining a Facebook group is not the same sort of activism as putting your life at risk in a real world conflict.
  • "Pay The Bills":http://bendauphinee.com/paythebills
    Interesting experiment in earning some money while looking for a job.
  • "Software Development for Developing Regions: Another Hat for Hackers":http://tier.cs.berkeley.edu/drupal/node/148
    Interesting idea about using skills like reversee engineering, code injection etc. for making software better suited to third world demands.
  • "India's surprising economic miracle":http://www.economist.com/node/17147648
    Will India's economy thrive when the global economy becomes more knowledge-intensive?

entry.title: Information Overload 2010-09-26
entry.content:
Being sick this week I had a lot of time to read, but most if it went into Bruce Sterling’s “Hacker Crackdown”:http://www.mit.edu/hacker/hacker.html and Joe Dunthorne’s “Submarine”:http://www.amazon.com/Submarine-Joe-Dunthorne/dp/0241143969. Anyway, here we go:

  • "Did 'Star Wars' become a toy story? ":http://herocomplex.latimes.com/2010/08/12/star-wars-was-born-a-long-time-ago-but-not-all-that-far-far-away-in-1972-filmmakers-george-lucas-and-gary-kurtz-wer/
    I admit to being quite a Star Wars nerd, the "Han shot first":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_shot_first kind who pretends Episode I-III never happened and who actually sat through the entire "Holiday special":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Star_Wars_Holiday_Special. If you are remotely like me, this article providing some insider information by "Gary Kurtz":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Kurtz will be quite an interesting read.
  • "Computers and Mathematical Notation":http://www.jsoftware.com/papers/camn.htm
    Interesting thoughts on how programming languages (J in this case) could influence mathematical notation by Turing Award winner "Kenneth E. Iverson":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_E._Iverson
  • "Common Programmer Health Problems":http://sheddingbikes.com/posts/1281257293.html
    Some sane advice we all occasionally are guilty of ignoring.
  • "We Are All Talk Radio Hosts":http://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2010/08/we-are-all-talk-radio-hosts/
    On strawberry jam, reasoning and cognitive bias.
  • "The Millennium Development Goal that really does work has been forgotten":http://aidwatchers.com/2010/09/the-millennium-development-goal-that-really-does-work-has-been-forgotten/
    Sure, we'll help you. Just not in a way so that you eventually can help yourself.
  • "The Anthropology of Hackers":http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2010/09/the-anthropology-of-hackers/63308/
    Outline of anthropologist Gabriella Coleman's course about hacker culture at NYU.
  • "Ten things to look for in a circumvention tool":https://blog.torproject.org/blog/ten-things-look-circumvention-tool
    By Roger Dingledine of Tor fame.
  • "This Ain't Your Daddy's Wumpus":http://nostarch.com/download/Lisp08.pdf
    Example chapter from the upcoming book "Land of Lisp":http://nostarch.com/lisp.htm (PDF).
  • "In Arabian Desert, a Sustainable City Rises":http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/26/arts/design/26masdar.html?_r=1&hp
    The first residents are starting to move into "Masdar":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masdar_City, a planned city built in Abu Dhabi. There seems to be some discussion about how much of a "real" city Masdar will be, but then Dubai didn't feel like a "real" place to me either, but more like a soulless agglomeration of skyscrapers and shopping malls.
